Kevin:

as an example, i'll riff on the "weather" design i posted earlier i=
n this
thread.

below is an "extension" of the weather media type design (i=
.e. adding this
will not break existing implemenations). Note the new optio=
nal
HTML.INPUT@name=3D"include-five-day-forecast" state transition element =
that
MAY appear in the HTML.FORM@class=3D"weather" block and the new
HTML.S=
PAN@class=3D"five-day-forecast" element that MAY appear in the
HTML.P@class=
=3D"current-weather" response.
<!-- this is the representation for current =
weather -->
<p class=3D"current-weather">
<span class=3D"zipcode" />
<span =
class=3D"location-name" />
<span class=3D"current-temp" />
<!-- new OPTIONA=
L element -->
<span class=3D"five-day-forecast" />
</p>

<!-- this affordan=
ce allows clients to get weather reports based on zipcode
-->
<form class=
=3D"weather" action=3D"..." method=3D"get">
<input type=3D"text" name=3D"zi=
pcode" value=3D"" />
<-- new OPTIONAL element, defaults to "false" -->
<inp=
ut type=3D"checkbox" name=3D"include-five-day-forecast" />
</form>

Now, he=
re is a design alteration that is a "breaking change" - a new
"version" - o=
f the weather media type design:
<!-- this affordance allows clients to get=
 weather reports based on zipcode
-->
<form class=3D"weather2" action=3D"..=
." method=3D"get">
<input type=3D"text" name=3D"zipcode" value=3D"" />
<!--=
 new REQUIRED element -->
<select name=3D"temperature-scale">
  <option val=
ue=3D"Fahrenheit">Fahrenheit</option>
  <option value=3D"Celsius">Celsius</=
option>
</select>
<-- new optional element, defaults to "false" -->
<input =
type=3D"checkbox" name=3D"include-five-day-forecast" />
</form>

Enforcing =
the Version Change
In this example, since I used an existing media type (te=
xt/html), changing
the media type identifier to enforce the version change =
is not a reasonable
option. Instead, servers that want to "force" this new =
version, must change
the identifier for the transition ("weather" -> "weath=
er2") - which is,
essentially a *new* transition - and stop including the "=
old" version
transition in responses. M2M clients will no longer be able to=
 find (and
activate) the expected transition ("weather"), preventing them f=
rom
participating with the server (they are now "broken"). H2M clients will=

likely be able to depend on the human driver to successfully handle this
e=
volution and will be able to continue talking with this server (they have
"=
evolved").

as a corollary to what i just said: i was thinkin=
g about, let's say in XML/XSD terms, a global attribute you can put on =
elements to signal that. but oftentimes, a version attribute somewhere does=
 this for all of the representation, effectively disallowing a client to co=
ntinue to proceed if it encounters an unknown version. the big disadvantage=
 of this "document-level attribute" is that it disallows the use =
of *everything*, including old stuff that still might be safe to use for th=
e client. which is the reason why version attributes often are a bit too di=
sruptive in a loosely coupled scenario.<br>


<br>
another approach to this=
 would be to remove this from representation design altogether and use rela=
tions to communicate extensions, something that has been discussed by mark =
nottingham in his recent blog post <a href=3D"http://www.mnot.net/blog/2011=
/10/25/web_api_versioning_smackdown" target=3D"_blank">http://www.mnot.net/=
blog/2011/<u></u>10/25/web_api_versioning_<u></u>smackdown</a> . you could =
possibly extend his method to also qualify those links as being mandatory o=
r not. the link-based extension mark proposes is an interesting approach, b=
ut doesn't work too well in cases where extensions need to be put in ce=
rtain places in existing representations (think documents instead of data),=
 instead of just being a bag of additional data clients can get to, if they=
 want to get it.<div>
